awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Towards Practical Fully Homomorphic Encryption
awd_abstract_narration:
Fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) allows an untrusted party to efficiently compute any compact function directly on ciphertexts.  When made available over an untrusted cloud server, data is submitted and returned in encrypted form, and the execution remains secure against malicious users. Early FHE proposals had rather disappointing efficiencies.  Recently new FHE schemes based on the difficulty of the learning with errors (LWE) problem emerged with orders of magnitude improvement over earlier constructions. This project addresses a variety of problems in engineering, computer science and mathematics all centered around the goal of bringing LWE-based homomorphic encryption techniques closer to practice which could impact the way society utilizes computing services.

The project team explores three research components. The first research component investigates algorithmic optimizations to speed up LWE-based schemes, and to develop optimized software implementations on CPUs and graphics processing units. Specifically, the investigators apply optimization techniques including changing the representation of the operands, batching, and precomputation. The team also aims to build a LWE-FHE based homomorphic instruction set. In another research component the project team develops application specific custom hardware to overcome inefficiencies of software platforms. Finally, we investigate the customization of parameters to match the needs of select lightweight cryptographic primitives.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded project carried out at Worcester Polytechnic Institute explores issues of practicality in the advancement of homomorphic encryption. Homomorphic encryption is a powerful new paradigm which has the potential to solve numerous issues of privacy and security in modern communications and cloud computing. In 2009, the discovery of secure mechanisms to allow for computation to be performed directly on ciphertexts generated much activity in the research community, leading to a rapid succession of new developments both at the very theoretical end of cryptography and in the field of cryptographic implementation. Yet the common expectation was that fully homomorphic encryption would not be achieved in practice in the near future.

Homomorphic encryption makes it possible for a server to perform computation on one's sensitive data without the server, or any party with unauthorized access to that server, ever able see the data itself. This is achieved by giving the server access only to specialized encryptions of the data and specialized algorithms for processing those encryptions. As examples, the user here could be a client of the server's website or could be outsourcing computation to the server.

This project, and others like it, tackled the enormous challenge of taking parts of the homomorphic encryption theory and transforming them into working pieces of software and high-end hardware instantiations. These practical building blocks are fully amenable to metrics of efficiency in both speed and storage and their parameter settings reflect the state of the art in cryptanalysis. In a short few years, we have seen orders of magnitude improvement in timings in and memory requirements. These advancements result not only from further exploration of the advanced mathematics involved in the subject such as the theory of lattices, number theory and computational complexity theory, but also cutting edge developments in algorithms and the innovative use of the latest high-end devices such as FPGAs (field-programmable gate arrays) and GPUs (graphics processing units). The solutions achieved in this project involve complex combinations of hardware and software components.

Specific achievements by the team over the three-year course of the project include:

F-NTRU (a new fully homomorphic encryption scheme based on Brown University's NTRU cryptosystem but combined with an innovative noise reduction technique in which ciphertexts are "flattened" to short vectors in a lattice); An efficient NTRU-MLS implementation (modular lattice based post-quantum signature scheme based on the NTRU cryptosystem); homomorphic block cipher evaluation (widely used as a benchmark application); our new cuHE Library (open source instruction library released on GitHub); trusted module (a hardware component that can perform homomorphic encryptions and decryptions in a reliable way, shielded from malware, on an ordinary computer); custom LTV hardware accelerator (hardware tailored for the fastest possible implementation of the 2012 cryptosystem developed by Lopez-Alt, Tromer and Vaikuntanathan); homomorphic evaluation of complex operations (algebraic operations on word-based encrypted data); homomorphic NTT evaluation (a highly efficient, highly parallel implementation of the number-theoretic transform, an essential building block for many applications); homomorphic sorting (the fastest currently available homomorphic sorting software); private information retrival (PIR, which allows anonymous queries to a database, for instance); and privatized web search, including queries as well as autocomplete.

Our broader impacts include a give-and-take interaction with mathematical researchers at Brown University, discussions with researchers in both engineering and computer science at INRIA, Seoul, Trier, Southern Brittany, etc., and numerous interactions with businesses having pressing needs for these sorts of security solutions.

This NSF project has funded training for students ranging from undergraduate to graduate, from practical to theoretical, from engineering to computer science. Graduate students directly participating in this project have developed both theoretical and applied skills in lattice-based HE schemes, custom application-specific ASIC development, GPGPU programming and parallel computing. Security issues arise at all levels of algorithm and software development for encryption as well as the specific implementation of such software.  These students have developed keen awareness of both attacks and countermeasures. While the core cryptography in the project is lattice-based quantum-resistant cryptography, students have also developed expertise with block ciphers and more mainstream public key cryptosystems. These are indispensable tools for a highly skilled worker moving on to industry, government laboratories or academia. 

But the impact on students is much broader than WPI's Vernam Lab. The PI offered a homomomorphic encryption module in his graduate-level course offering and research students at WPI are trying to connect homomorphic encryption to other fields such as machine learning. Over a dozen undergraduate students have carried out their senior thesis ("Major Qualifying Project") work with members of the team.  These are just a few aspects of WPI's cybersecurity initiative, where we take measures to infuse security considerations into the curriculum at every level.
